text: I had this belief that almost anybody can learn anything. People have different interests, not everybody wants to learn everything. But I find that if you're having trouble learning something, it's just because something's not clicking. There's just something that you're misunderstanding or that other people see that you're not seeing. And if people could just describe it in the way that matched YOUR mental model, then you could learn it.
speaker: Jackie Bavaro
context: Lenny asks Jackie about her motivation for writing her product management books. Jackie explains her philosophy on learning, which drove her to write accessible guides for PM interviews. She believes that when people struggle to learn something, it's usually because the information isn't being presented in a way that matches their mental framework, rather than an inability to understand the concept itself.
text_ko: 저는 거의 누구나 무엇이든 배울 수 있다고 믿어요. 사람들마다 관심사가 다르고 모든 사람이 다 모든 걸 배우고 싶어하는 건 아니에요. 그런데 뭔가를 배우는 데 어려움을 겪는다면 그건 그냥 뭔가가 딱 안 맞아서예요. 본인이 오해하고 있거나 다른 사람들이 보는 걸 못 보고 있는 부분이 있는 거죠. 다른 사람들이 그걸 당신의 멘탈 모델(mental model)에 맞게 설명해 주기만 하면 배울 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我一直相信一个道理，几乎所有人都能学会任何东西。当然了，每个人兴趣不一样，也不是人人都想学所有的东西。但我发现，如果你觉得某样东西怎么都学不会，那肯定是哪里没开窍。肯定有什么地方你理解错了，或者别人看明白的东西你还没看透。如果有人能用符合你思维方式的方法来解释，你绝对能学会。
text_es: Siempre he creído que casi cualquier persona puede aprender lo que sea. La gente tiene intereses diferentes, no todo el mundo quiere aprender de todo. Pero me he dado cuenta de que si te está costando trabajo aprender algo, es simplemente porque algo no te está haciendo "clic". Hay algo que no estás captando bien o que otros ven pero tú no logras ver. Y si la gente pudiera explicártelo de una manera que encaje con TU forma de pensar, entonces sí lo podrías aprender.

text: I very much saw the PM's role is a person who wants to say no to everybody. I was like, 'All these people want us to do stuff and we would do way too much and we would never get anything important done if we just said yes to them. I need to say no to people.' And I got into this defensive mindset and sometimes people would come to me with ideas and I'd be like, 'Are you telling me I can't do my job right?' And I would just try to say no to them as efficiently and effectively as possible.
speaker: Jackie Bavaro
context: Lenny asks Jackie about mistakes she made early in her career at Asana. Jackie describes how she initially misunderstood the PM role as being a gatekeeper who needed to reject ideas to maintain focus. This defensive approach backfired when she shut down her boss's suggestion, leading to a pivotal learning moment about the importance of collaboration over control in product management.
text_ko: 저는 프로덕트 매니저(PM)의 역할을 거의 '모든 사람에게 아니라고 말해야 하는 사람'이라고 생각했어요. 사람들이 우리한테 이것저것 해 달라고 하면, 전부 다 받아주면 우리가 할 일이 너무 많아져서 정작 중요한 건 하나도 못 하게 될 거라고 생각했죠. 그래서 사람들에게 아니라고 말해야 한다고요. 그렇게 방어적인 마음가짐이 됐고, 사람들이 아이디어를 들고 오면 저는 '제가 제 일을 제대로 못한다는 말이에요?'라고 느끼곤 했어요. 그래서 가능한 한 효율적이고 효과적으로 거절하려고만 했어요.
text_zh: 我当时觉得产品经理(PM)的职责就是要对所有人说"不"。我想着，"这么多人都想让我们做这做那，如果我们都答应的话，肯定会摊子铺得太大，真正重要的事情反而做不成。我得学会拒绝。"然后我就陷入了一种防御心理，有时候别人来找我提想法，我就会想"你这是在说我不会干活吗？"我就想着怎么能最快最有效地把他们拒绝掉。
text_es: Yo veía el rol del PM como alguien que tiene que decirle que no a todo el mundo. Pensaba: 'Toda esta gente quiere que hagamos cosas y acabaríamos haciendo demasiado, nunca terminaríamos nada importante si les dijéramos que sí a todos. Tengo que decir que no.' Y me puse súper defensivo, a veces la gente venía con ideas y yo reaccionaba como '¿Me estás diciendo que no sé hacer mi trabajo?' Y básicamente trataba de decirles que no de la manera más rápida y efectiva posible.

text: For the next two weeks, say yes to everything. I think you can find a way to do your job and still say yes to people. You can say, 'yes, I agree. That is a real problem. Yes. I think we could test this design with users' and just see what's different with two weeks of saying yes to people instead of no. And I realized that this protectiveness and lockdownness that I had really wasn't something I needed and it wasn't something that was serving me because it meant that I couldn't have real collaboration with the other people around me.
speaker: Jackie Bavaro
context: Jackie continues explaining how her coach helped her overcome her tendency to immediately reject ideas from colleagues. The coach challenged her to spend two weeks saying yes instead of no, which taught Jackie that she could maintain her PM responsibilities while being more collaborative. This experience showed her that being overly protective of the product roadmap was actually hindering effective teamwork.
text_ko: 다음 2주 동안은 모든 것에 '네'라고 해보세요. 일을 하면서도 사람들에게 '네'라고 할 방법은 찾을 수 있을 거예요. 예를 들어 '네, 동의해요. 그건 진짜 문제네요. 네. 이 디자인을 사용자 대상으로 테스트해볼 수 있을 것 같아요'라고 말해보고, 2주 동안 '아니요' 대신 '네'라고 했을 때 뭐가 달라지는지 지켜보세요. 그걸 해보면서 제가 가지고 있던 그런 보호적이고 폐쇄적인 태도는 사실 필요 없고 저에게도 도움이 되지 않는다는 걸 깨달았어요. 그런 태도 때문에 주변 사람들과 진짜 협업을 할 수가 없었거든요.
text_zh: 接下来两周，不管什么事都先说"行"。我觉得你完全可以把工作做好的同时，也对别人说"行"。你可以说，"行，我同意。这确实是个问题。没错。我觉得我们可以让用户测试一下这个设计"，就试试看连续两周对别人说"行"而不是"不行"会有什么不一样。后来我意识到，我之前那种防御心理，什么都要把控的心态，其实根本没必要，对我也没好处，因为这样我就没法跟身边的人真正协作了。
text_es: Durante las próximas dos semanas, di que sí a todo. Creo que puedes encontrar la manera de hacer tu trabajo y aún así decirle que sí a la gente. Puedes decir: "sí, estoy de acuerdo. Ese es un problema real. Sí. Creo que podríamos probar este diseño con usuarios" y simplemente ver qué cambia con dos semanas diciéndole que sí a la gente en lugar de que no. Y me di cuenta de que esa actitud tan protectora y cerrada que tenía realmente no era algo que necesitara y no me estaba sirviendo de nada porque significaba que no podía tener una verdadera colaboración con las otras personas a mi alrededor.

text: I worked with her for several months, but then once that was gone, then I did start to find that personally I would make things bigger when I had a coach, because I had something that I knew how to solve on my own. And I'd bring it to the coach, and then all of a sudden it felt like it was a big deal rather than a little deal. I've gone in and out of coaching, but I do it when I have a thing that I want to work on.
speaker: Jackie Bavaro
context: Lenny asks Jackie about her experience with coaching and advice for PMs considering getting a coach. Jackie explains her personal approach to coaching - she prefers working with coaches when she has specific issues to address rather than ongoing general coaching. She discovered that bringing small problems to a coach sometimes made them feel unnecessarily magnified, so she uses coaching strategically for targeted skill development.
text_ko: 그분과 몇 달 동안 함께 일했어요. 그게 끝나고 나서는 개인적으로 코치가 있을 때 사소한 걸 더 크게 만드는 경향이 있더라고요. 혼자서 해결할 수 있는 걸 코치에게 가져가면 갑자기 그게 작은 일이 아니라 큰일인 것처럼 느껴졌어요. 코칭은 받다 말다 했는데, 다만 제가 집중해서 해결하고 싶은 일이 있을 때만 다시 받는 편이에요.
text_zh: 我跟她合作了好几个月，但后来没有教练了，我发现我个人会把事情想得更复杂。本来是我自己能解决的问题，一带到教练那里，突然感觉变成了大事，而不是小事了。我断断续续地接受过coaching，但现在只有在遇到特别想解决的问题时才会去找教练。
text_es: Trabajé con ella varios meses, pero después cuando ya no estaba, me di cuenta de que personalmente tendía a hacer más grandes los problemas cuando tenía coach, porque tenía algo que yo sabía resolver solo. Se lo llevaba al coach y de repente se sentía como algo súper importante en lugar de algo menor. He entrado y salido del coaching, pero lo hago cuando tengo algo específico en lo que quiero trabajar.

text: After a little bit of that, I was like, 'It might be easier if I just go, I might be able save you some time and some energy if I just joined you.' And it was a way that I took myself into this higher level meeting, framing it as something that was going to help out my boss. And it did. It wasn't dishonest, but it was a pretty effective way of advocating to get into this meeting.
speaker: Jackie Bavaro
context: Lenny asks what kept Jackie at Asana for eight years. Jackie explains how she grew within the company by strategically advocating for inclusion in higher-level planning meetings. When she found herself constantly asking her boss questions after his planning committee meetings, she positioned joining the meetings as a way to help him be more efficient rather than simply asking for more responsibility.
text_ko: 그걸 좀 해보다가 저는 '내가 그냥 같이 가면 더 쉬울 것 같고, 그러면 네 시간하고 에너지도 좀 절약될 텐데'라고 생각했어요. 그렇게 스스로를 포지셔닝해서 더 높은 수준의 회의에 들어갈 명분을 만든 거예요—상사를 돕는다는 명목으로요. 실제로 효과가 있었어요. 정직하지 않은 건 아니었지만, 미팅에 들어가기 위해 자신을 어필하는 꽤 효과적인 방법이었어요.
text_zh: 后来我就想，"要不我直接参加吧，这样可能更简单，我加入进来可能还能帮你们节省点时间和精力。" 我就是这样把自己弄进了这个高层会议，表面上说是要帮老板的忙。确实也起到作用了。这么做不算不诚实，但确实是个很有效的方式，让我成功混进了这个会议。
text_es: Después de un rato de eso, me dije, 'Oye, tal vez sería más fácil si voy yo, capaz que les ahorro tiempo y energía si me uno a ustedes.' Y fue la manera en que me colé a esta reunión de alto nivel, presentándolo como algo que iba a ayudar a mi jefe. Y sí funcionó. No fue deshonesto, pero fue una forma bastante efectiva de abrirme paso para entrar a esa reunión.

text: What I did is I wrote a document on the Local Universal Team, so I called it Local Universal Strategy. And I can't remember what I put in this document. I put it in just random... What my plan was. But once I wrote it down and shared it with people, then I started getting feedback on it. And then I could start to feel my way to what people meant to strategy.
speaker: Jackie Bavaro
context: Lenny asks Jackie to define what strategy means in product management. Jackie explains how she initially struggled to understand strategy when she received feedback at Google that she needed to be 'more strategic' but no one could explain what that meant. She learned by writing down her strategic thinking and getting feedback, which helped her understand what others expected from strategic work.
text_ko: 제가 한 일은 로컬 유니버설 팀(Local Universal Team)에 관한 문서를 쓴 거예요. 그래서 그걸 로컬 유니버설 전략(Local Universal Strategy)이라고 이름 붙였어요. 그 문서에 정확히 뭘 적었는지 잘 기억이 안 나요. 그냥 아무렇게나, 그때 제 계획을 대충 적어놨던 것 같아요. 그런데 일단 적어서 사람들과 공유하니까 피드백이 오기 시작했고, 그러면서 사람들이 말하는 ‘전략’이 정확히 무슨 뜻인지 감을 잡을 수 있었어요.
text_zh: 我当时就写了一个关于本地全球团队的文件，我叫它"本地全球战略"。具体写了什么我都记不清了，就是随便写了一些我的想法和计划。但是一旦写下来跟大家分享了，就开始有人给反馈了。然后我就能慢慢摸索出大家对这个战略的真正想法是什么。
text_es: Lo que hice fue escribir un documento sobre el Equipo Universal Local, así que le puse Estrategia Universal Local. Y no me acuerdo qué metí en ese documento. Puse cosas medio al azar... lo que tenía planeado. Pero una vez que lo escribí y lo compartí con la gente, empecé a recibir feedback. Y ahí fue cuando empecé a tantear qué era lo que la gente realmente entendía por estrategia.

text: Three parts of strategy are your vision. This is your inspiring picture of what the future looks like. And then you've got your strategic framework. This is where you're saying, 'Here is the market we're going after. Here's what success looks like. And here are our big bets on what we think it takes to win that market.' And then the third part is the roadmap. This is where you work backwards from your vision.
speaker: Jackie Bavaro
context: Jackie breaks down her framework for product strategy after years of learning what strategy actually means. She identifies three essential components that any complete strategy should include: an inspiring vision of the future, a strategic framework that defines the market and approach, and a roadmap that works backward from the vision to ensure the plan is realistic and achievable.
text_ko: 전략(strategy)은 세 부분으로 나눌 수 있어요. 첫 번째는 비전(vision)이에요 — 미래가 어떤 모습일지 보여 주는 영감을 주는 그림이에요. 두 번째는 전략적 프레임워크(strategic framework)예요. 우리가 노리는 시장(market)이 어디인지, 성공이 어떤 모습인지, 그리고 그 시장에서 이기기 위해 우리가 크게 베팅할 것들이 무엇인지 정하는 곳이에요. 세 번째는 로드맵(roadmap)이에요. 비전에서 역산해 단계별 실행 계획으로 옮기는 부분이에요.
text_zh: 战略分三个部分。首先是愿景(vision)，就是你对未来的一个激动人心的蓝图。然后是战略框架(strategic framework)，在这里你要说清楚"我们要进军哪个市场，什么叫成功，以及我们押注什么才能拿下这个市场"。第三部分是路线图(roadmap)，就是从你的愿景倒推回来制定具体步骤。
text_es: Tres elementos conforman tu estrategia. Primero tienes tu visión. Esta es esa imagen inspiradora de cómo se ve el futuro. Luego tienes tu marco estratégico (strategic framework). Aquí es donde dices: 'Este es el mercado al que vamos. Así se ve el éxito para nosotros. Y estas son nuestras grandes apuestas sobre lo que creemos que se necesita para conquistar ese mercado.' Y el tercer elemento es la hoja de ruta (roadmap). Aquí trabajas hacia atrás desde tu visión.
